headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning, and welcome to Harley-Davidson's Fourth Quarter 2009 Conference Call. Today's call will be webcast live on harley-davidson.com and supported by slides that can be accessed by clicking on Investor Relations, then Events and Announcements. Our
componenttext: Good morning, and welcome to Harley-Davidson's Fourth Quarter 2009 Conference Call. Today's call will be webcast live on harley-davidson.com and supported by slides that can be accessed by clicking on Investor Relations, then Events and Announcements. Our comments today will include forward-looking statements that are subject to risks that could cause actual results to be materially different. Those risks include, among others, matters we have noted in our latest earnings release and filings with the SEC. Harley-Davidson disclaims any obligation to update information on this call. This morning, you'll hear from Harley-Davidson's CEO, Keith Wandell; CFO, John Olin; and President of Harley-Davidson Financial Services, Larry Hund. At the close of prepared comments, we will open the call for questions. Keith?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Amy. And good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call. We've got a lot of ground to cover this morning, so we'll get right to it. And as you saw in the press release today, Harley-Davidson reported its first quarterly loss in m
componenttext: Thank you, Amy. And good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call. We've got a lot of ground to cover this morning, so we'll get right to it. And as you saw in the press release today, Harley-Davidson reported its first quarterly loss in many years, with full year revenues and profits decreased from last year. These results were not surprising. In fact, they were as we had expected, because they were the direct result of the economic climate and the decisive actions we took throughout the year, actions to deal not just with the recession, but to position our company for the future through the go-forward strategy that we unveiled in October. We firmly believe the short-term pain that Harley-Davidson is going through is a result of our actions, is worth the longer-term gain that we expect to see as a result. And we have confidence that we're doing the right things to manage our business prudently and effectively in this economy, and to restore Harley-Davidson to greater profitability going forward. So let's take a look at 2009 and our actions. And then I want to turn my attention to what lies ahead. When I joined Harley-Davidson in May, we set out two key priorities for our team. Firs was to continue to take the actions necessary, and execute effectively on our strategy to manage the business in the current economic environment. And at the same, it was even more essential that we develop a clear, comprehensive and powerful strategy to maximize our opportunities for growth and profitability going forward. And so looking at our actions to execute effectively in the current environment, we reduced shipment volumes significantly to align our inventories. We embarked on major restructuring of our production operations. We obtained funding for the lending activities of HDFS [Harley-Davidson Financial Services] and positioned HDFS for solid footing in 2010, and launched our go-forward business strategy to deliver results by focusing on the four key pillars of our strategy, which are growth, continuous improvement, leadership development and sustainability.Under our strategy, we are focusing our investment behind the uniquely strong Harley-Davidson brand as the most attractive path to sustained long-term growth through products and experiences, global expansion, outreach to new customers and our commitment to core customers. And as we look at the year in front of us, we expect 2010 to continue to be challenging. Our strategy and the performance goals that we have laid out through 2014 are based on an appropriately prudent approach. And our growth targets will take hard work and intense focus to reach, but we believe they are imminently achievable and appropriately conservative.But even in an environment where consumers are more practical and cautious, we believe that people still dream about the Harley-Davidson experience. And everything we see indicates that the brand is in stronger, stronger than ever both in the U.S. and globally. So we will continue to solidify our position and execute on our go-forward strategy, including bringing exciting products to market like the Forty-Eight that we are introducing today and which, like the other Dark Custom bikes, is intended to reach new young adult customers. In addition to our focus on growing core and outreach markets in North America, we will also continue to focus on expanding the brand in international markets. Harley-Davidson's brand appeal around the world is as strong or stronger than ever. And so in summary, our fourth quarter and full year 2009 results are a direct reflection of the economy and the actions that we took to manage the business prudently and effectively in the current environment and more importantly for the future.While we expect 2010 to be another challenging year for the industry and for Harley-Davidson, the Harley-Davidson brand has exceptional strength and we're highly focused on continuing to grow the reach of our brand around the world. And we have a great conviction that our go-forward strategy is focusing our company in the right direction and that we are executing our strategy with appropriate urgency. So with that, I'd like to say thanks and let me turn it over to John Olin for the numbers and then more of the details.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith. This morning I'll discuss some of the details around our financial results, provide an update on our restructuring activities and discuss an expectations for 2010. During the fourth quarter, Harley-Davidson Inc. revenue from continuing oper
componenttext: Thanks, Keith. This morning I'll discuss some of the details around our financial results, provide an update on our restructuring activities and discuss an expectations for 2010. During the fourth quarter, Harley-Davidson Inc. revenue from continuing operations was down 40.2% and we recognized a loss for the first time in recent history. This loss was expected as a result of ongoing restructuring activity, costs associated with exiting the Buell product line and the impact of shipping 53% fewer bikes than the fourth quarter of last year.While the shipment reduction negatively impacted the quarter's results, the positive news is that our U.S. dealer network had a year-end inventory level that was significantly lower than last year and we believe appropriate for the current environment which I'll talk more about shortly.Moving on to Slide 11, retail sales of Harley-Davidson motorcycles were down worldwide during the fourth quarter and the full year 2009 compared to last year. A few points to note about retail sales. In the fourth quarter, our worldwide retail sales rate was flat compared to last quarter. In international markets we saw another sequential improvement in retail sales rate and after being down for three consecutive quarters, Europe was up slightly in the fourth quarter. Regarding market share, our U.S. market share decreased by 4.8 percentage points in the quarter as we lacked a strong fourth quarter 2008 share increase of 4.4 percentage points. Also, driving the decrease in fourth quarter 2009 market share were strong sales in the performance segment due to significant price discounting during the quarter. For the full year, our market share was up 7.9 percentage points versus 2008.On Slide 12, our U.S. dealer networks year-end retail inventory was down 18,000 units compared to last year. It was the third consecutive year we significantly reduced dealer inventory and we remain committed to the task of balancing supply in line with demand. As retail conditions remain challenging, we continue to execute our plan to help protect the integrity of our dealer network. In October, we estimated that 15 to 30 additional dealer points could close over the next six months. During the fourth quarter, 14 dealer points closed. So during 2009, a total of 28 dealer points closed. We continue to expect approximately 15 additional dealer points will close in the next three months.On Slide 13, you will see wholesale shipments to our dealers for the full year were down 26.5% to 223,000 units. Of that total, Sportster represented 21.2% of shipments just slightly more than 2008 full year total. Mix shifted between the Custom and Touring families compared to 2008, primarily driven by the new Tri Glide models and shipments to international markets increased to 35% of the total.On the next slide, you'll see revenue in all categories of the Motorcycle and Related Products segment was down in the fourth quarter and the full year. The 45.6% decrease in Harley-Davidson motorcycle revenue during the fourth quarter was primarily a result of lower shipments, partially offset by favorable shipment mix and favorable foreign currency exchange. P&A [Parts and Accessories] and General Merchandise revenue were down less than motorcycle revenue. Both were an important part of our growth strategy and we're excited about the prospects of these high margin businesses in the future.For example, the Fit Shop is a new P&A concept. It enables sales people to show customers how handle bars, seats, controls and suspension affect riding position comfort and confidence. General Merchandise just launched the new Pink Label Collection, a portion of the proceeds will support the Breast Cancer Network of Strength. Both support our strategy to reach a more diverse rider base. As retail sales, shipments and revenue have been down due to the recession, we have been intensely focused on improving our cost structure and structuring the business to be stronger and more profitable in the future. Throughout 2009, we announced significant restructuring efforts that will result in reduced administrative costs, reduced excess capacity and increased focus on our core operations. During the fourth quarter, we made the decision to consolidate a three vehicle test facility into one location further streamlining operations. The estimated total costs and savings associated with our 2009 restructuring activities are summarized on Slide 15.During the fourth quarter, we shut down Buell production. The financial results related to Buell will continue to be reported as a component of income from operations. Related exit costs will be recorded as restructuring expenses and gross profit will continue to include earnings on the sale of our remaining Buell inventory. In 2009, we recorded approximately $116 million of the estimated $125 million in costs related to exiting Buell.On Slide 17, you'll see our total 2009 restructuring costs were $221 million, which exceeded our estimated range of $190 million to $210 million mainly driven by higher Buell restructuring costs. However, total Buell exit costs are still expected to be $125 million as there was favorability in the gross margin impact associated with the Buell product line exit.Restructuring savings were $91 million, slightly above the high end of our expected range. We now expect total restructuring and impairment costs will be between $430 million and $460 million through 2012 and we continue to expect total cumulative annual savings associated with our restructuring to be between $240 million and $260 million. Expected costs and savings by year are provided on the slide.On Slide 18, you will see gross margin in the quarter decreased to 20.3% of revenue compared to last year. As expected, gross margin was negatively impacted primarily by lower shipments and Buell exit costs. But also by unfavorable manufacturing costs due to loss absorption. Overall, material costs favorable mix and higher-than-expected productivity provided some favorable offset. Full year gross margin was 32.3% of revenue and we continue to be very pleased with the gross margin strength of our core business despite volume declines of over 26% from 2008.On Slide 19, operating margin as a percent of revenue for the fourth quarter was a negative 29%, which was impacted by lower gross margin of $254 million, restructuring and asset impairments of $120 million and higher SG&A expenses. Full year operating margin decreased to 7.3% as a result of lower gross margin and restructuring and asset impairment charges. SG&A finished the year down by $91 million driven by an estimated $83 million in restructuring savings.Now moving on to our Financial Services segment. During the quarter HDFS recorded an operating loss of $7.1 million, an improvement of $17.8 million compared to last year. The main drivers of this improvement were income from past off-balance sheet securitization increased by $18.1 million during the quarter. Impairments to retain securitization interest for the fourth quarter 2009 were $9.8 million compared to $25.3 million impairment in the fourth quarter of 2008. Provision for retail loan losses increased by $19.9 million during the quarter, primarily due to a higher balance of held for invested receivables versus the prior year. And the provision for wholesale loan losses decreased by $7 million relative to the fourth quarter of 2008. This decrease resulted primarily from lower outstanding receivables due to reduced motorcycle inventory in the dealer network from a year ago.It is encouraging that our credit risk assumptions in both the retail and wholesale portfolio did not change significantly from the third quarter of 2009. The remaining $11.1 million of improvement is primarily the result of a fourth quarter 2008 provision for lower of cost or market adjustments on held-for-sale receivables. There is no comparable item in the fourth quarter of 2009 as these receivables were reclassified to held for investment at the end of the second quarter of 2009.On a full year basis, HDFS incurred $118 million loss largely due to $101 million of one-time items recorded during the year. In October, we said we expected HDFS to incur loss into the next couple of quarters due to seasonality, lower recovery values and higher cost of debt. Since then, HDFS continued to access the debt capital markets at relatively attractive cost of funds and repay the $600 million, 15% intercompany loan to Harley-Davidson, Inc. H-D, Inc. will hold the debt and will incur rebated interest expense.Repayment of this debt to H-D, Inc. positively impacted HDFS' fourth quarter results and going forward, we believe HDFS' cost of funds will be more reflective of current market interest rates. We expect the new interest rate structure will assist us in moving to profitability in 2010. Now Larry will review HDFS' operations and portfolio performance.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. During the fourth quarter, HDFS originated $284 million in retail motorcycle loans, down 25% compared to last year, primarily due to lower retail sales of Harley-Davidson motorcycles in the U.S. For the full year, HDFS originated $2 billion
componenttext: Thanks, John. During the fourth quarter, HDFS originated $284 million in retail motorcycle loans, down 25% compared to last year, primarily due to lower retail sales of Harley-Davidson motorcycles in the U.S. For the full year, HDFS originated $2 billion in retail motorcycle loans, down 29% compared to 2008. HDFS retail market share of new Harley-Davidson motorcycles sold in the U.S. was down nearly five percentage points to 48.8% in 2009 compared to 2008 due to an increase in cash buyers and also due to competition, particularly in the prime-rated customer segment.At the end of the fourth quarter, of the approximately $4.8 billion of receivables that were classified as held for investment, $4 billion were retail and $863 million were wholesale. We are pleased with the progress resulting from the significant underwriting adjustments we made in 2009. We continue to see improved performance on early-stage delinquencies and defaults for loans originated in 2009 compared to the prior year.At the end of 2009, 80% to 85% of our new loan originations were primed compared to approximately 75% in previous years. We continue to monitor the performance of these new originations very closely, and we will make changes to our underwriting standards that we deem appropriate. The impact of the recession and high unemployment continue to drive delinquencies and credit losses. The 30-day delinquency rate for managed retail motorcycle loans at December 31, 2009, was 6.51%, up slightly over 2008. Our increased collections' staffing levels and modified collection strategies have enabled us to manage delinquency levels close to last year, despite increase in unemployment in the U.S. Annualized retail credit losses increased to 2.86% for the full year in 2008, and were driven by a higher frequency of loss and a decline in the recovery values of repossessed motorcycles.So in conclusion, as John mentioned, we continue to make significant progress in improving our liquidity position and reducing our cost of funds. As we work through the winter months and given continued high unemployment rates in the U.S., we expect to continue to see higher levels of delinquent loans and retail credit losses in the near term. We believe our underwriting criteria are appropriate, and we will continue to evaluate them on an ongoing basis. Now let me turn it back to John.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. One of the top areas of focus in 2009 was to obtain funding to support HDFS' lending activities. During the fourth quarter, HDFS obtained $1.8 billion of funding. Last quarter, we said we were engaged in reviewing our strategic options to f
componenttext: Thanks, Larry. One of the top areas of focus in 2009 was to obtain funding to support HDFS' lending activities. During the fourth quarter, HDFS obtained $1.8 billion of funding. Last quarter, we said we were engaged in reviewing our strategic options to find more diversified and cost-effective funding in order to meet HDFS' goal of providing credit, while delivering appropriate returns in profitability. The process is progressing as we continue our discussion with several institutions. Realistically, we recognized that this is a challenge. However, we remain cautiously optimistic that we can find additional opportunities to improve HDFS' funding profile. In the meantime, we are pleased with HDFS' fourth quarter results, and are seeing some positive signs as we move into 2010.On Slide 24, you'll see our overall cash position and liquidity strategy. We ended this quarter with $1.7 billion of cash and marketable securities. This is a significant and welcomed improvement in liquidity from just one year ago, and we believe is an appropriate level given the uncertain economy. Of the total $1.7 billion, HDFS ended the year with $489 million in cash after repaying H-D, Inc. the $600 million it borrowed in February of 2009. Additionally, HDFS has access to approximately $2 billion of available liquidity through bank credit and asset-backed conduit facilities. As of the end of 2009, we believe we have met HDFS' anticipated 2010 funding needs throughout 2009 actions. During the year, we expect to pre-fund our 2011 needs through the capital markets, and by renewing a portion of the bank credit and asset-backed conduit facilities.Going forward, our strategy will be to maintain a minimum of 12 months of liquidity in cash and/or credit facilities. We will carry higher cash balances until we see stabilization and improvement in the economy, capital and credit markets and our company's credit ratings. We will continue to try to diversify our funding profile through a combination of short-term and long-term funding vehicles, reduce our reliance on the term asset-backed securitization market and continue to pursue all avenues to obtain cost-effective funding. Now I'll review the remaining Harley-Davidson financials on Slide 25.On a continuing basis, Harley-Davidson Inc. 2009 revenue, net income and earnings per share were down compared to last year mainly due to significant one-time items related to restructuring and asset impairment charges and the reclassification of HDFS receivables during the year. On Slide 26, I would like to highlight two items. First, with regards to operating cash, despite the large drop in motorcycle shipments and the restructuring spending that we incurred, we were able to generate operating cash of over $600 million, which included a fourth quarter contribution of $215 million to our pension plans.And second, our tax rate increased significantly in 2009 relative to 2008, primarily due to the one-time charge for the Wisconsin tax law change and the non-deductible HDFS goodwill write-off as well as the impact of reduced earnings. In 2010, we expect the full year effective tax rate will be approximately 36.5% from continuing operations.We are proceeding with our plan to sell MV Agusta. As a result, MV Agusta's assets and liabilities have been classified as held for sale and its financial results have been presented as discontinued operations for all periods presented. During the fourth quarter, we wrote down the carrying value of MV Agusta's assets resulting in non-cash of $53 million net of related tax benefits. For the fourth quarter and full year, we recognize a loss from discontinued operations. The details are on Slide 27.Now I'd like to talk about two important changes in our financial reporting. First, in the first quarter of 2010, FAS 166 and 167 will be adopted and approximately $1.9 billion of receivables and related debt will be brought back onto our balance sheet. Adoption will also result in a small adjustment to retained earnings. Upon adoption, we expect to remain in compliance with all our debt covenants. We will provide more details in the 2009 10-K.The second important change to our financials also involves HDFS. With the complexity and changing dynamics of the Financial Services business, we feel that it is important for our stakeholders to see more detail around our motorcycle and Financial Services segment. Therefore, in the 10-K, we will begin providing consolidating financial information that will breakdown the income statement, balance sheet and statement of cash flows for each segment.So all in all, 2009 was a challenging year. But we are confident that we have taken the appropriate actions to reserve greater profitability and drive long-term growth. We expect 2010 to be another challenging year. As a result, we expect Harley-Davidson motorcycle shipments in 2010 to be between 201,000 and 212,000 motorcycles, down 5% to 10% from 2009 as a result of two key factors. First, we expect the global economy to remain challenging with continued high unemployment and low consumer confidence in United States. Second, we expect continued price competition from other manufacturers as they reduce excess inventories. We also anticipate price competition at the local level as retailers discount excess inventory driven by contraction of the dealer network.In 2010, we will take a conservative approach to shipment volumes as we continue to work with our dealers to aggressively balance supply in line with demand. And when demand improves, we will be ready to increase production. We expect gross margins to be between 32% and 33.5% for the full year. And capital expenditures are expected to be between $235 million and $255 million which includes approximately $95 million to $110 million in restructuring capital.As we put 2009 behind us, it is important to note that despite significantly lower volumes and restructuring spending, Harley-Davidson remains a very strong company with an incredibly powerful brand. Our strength is evidenced by our solid gross margins and our ability to generate positive cash from the Motorcycle segment in a challenging business environment. We'll continue to take the necessary actions to manage through the economic downturn and execute our long-term strategy. And now let's open the call up to your questions.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010

componenttext: Tim, on the slide on Page 17, we have the actuals how they fit in for 2009. So 2009 the actual costs for the Motorcycle segment was $221 million and that was 65% cash. The standings were $91 million and that was 91% SG&A, which equates to $83 million on a full year basis. And then the slides that are posted that you'll have access to also go through 2010, '11 and '12 and give you amount of cash as well as the split between SG&A and cost of goods sold.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the savings though right, but as far as the restructuring how do you -- are those will be floater? I mean in your -- and again as you reported that you show a total and then you kind of show how that's in the fourth quarter. But going forward, how do y
componenttext: On the savings though right, but as far as the restructuring how do you -- are those will be floater? I mean in your -- and again as you reported that you show a total and then you kind of show how that's in the fourth quarter. But going forward, how do you expect that? I guess another way to ask it, is the 32% to 33.5% gross margin guidance for the year, that does not include any restructuring charges at all, correct?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Correct, Tim. All the restructuring -- anything that's classified as restructuring expense is broken out on a separate line on the P&L underneath SG&A. So we've got the gross profit, selling, SG&A expenses and then restructuring is broken out separately.
componenttext: Correct, Tim. All the restructuring -- anything that's classified as restructuring expense is broken out on a separate line on the P&L underneath SG&A. So we've got the gross profit, selling, SG&A expenses and then restructuring is broken out separately. So there is no restructuring expense in the cost of goods sold or in the gross margin. Now what we did have in the exit of Buell of the $116 million of restructuring expenses, $71 million went through the restructuring line and there was another $45 million that's not classified as restructuring expense but that money was necessary to move the product. Basically it was to discount the product as well as to take care of obsolete inventories that does go through gross margin. So we will have a one-time gross margin expense in 2009 of $44.8 million that we would not expect to repeat next year.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On HDFS, it appears again that your delinquencies and your credit losses are kind of leveling out at the fourth quarter run rate. Is -- should we perceive that and from a reserve standpoint going forward, is that kind of a fair way to look at it?
componenttext: On HDFS, it appears again that your delinquencies and your credit losses are kind of leveling out at the fourth quarter run rate. Is -- should we perceive that and from a reserve standpoint going forward, is that kind of a fair way to look at it?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't we have given forward-looking guidance here, but I would say that certainly we saw some stabilization and recovery values on repossessed motorcycles as we got into the last couple of months of the year. And certainly, we're going to be watching th
componenttext: I don't we have given forward-looking guidance here, but I would say that certainly we saw some stabilization and recovery values on repossessed motorcycles as we got into the last couple of months of the year. And certainly, we're going to be watching that very closely as we get into next year. As you remember, we had taken up reserve levels in the third quarter based on fourth quarter performance those reserve levels stayed fairly consistent with where they were at the end of the third quarter.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then related to HDFS, Keith, you guys have said and John that you're looking at diversifying your funding. Also, could you look at other structures for HDFS while still keeping some of the ownership. Could you maybe give us an update on that and break
componenttext: And then related to HDFS, Keith, you guys have said and John that you're looking at diversifying your funding. Also, could you look at other structures for HDFS while still keeping some of the ownership. Could you maybe give us an update on that and breaking -- and besides being more transparent which we thank you for in HDFS. Is that maybe also a precursor to something that you guys maybe looking at?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, let me answer the second part first Tim is, one is that a lot of this stuff is coming back on the balance sheet in terms of receivables and debt. We think it's very important for everyone to see the separate businesses. And certainly, the high margin
componenttext: No, let me answer the second part first Tim is, one is that a lot of this stuff is coming back on the balance sheet in terms of receivables and debt. We think it's very important for everyone to see the separate businesses. And certainly, the high margin Motorcycle business that we've got that has very little debt and very high margins and the reinvestment returns or the returns on equity that we've gotten off of our Financial Service business. So we want to start to show the different dynamics of the business. So that doesn't have anything to do with looking forward at HDFS from a strategic standpoint. But what we have said a couple of quarters ago that we were evaluating our options, our strategic options as it relates to obtaining a more diversified low-cost funds for HDFS. Our goal at HDFS has been to provide credit while balancing appropriate returns and profitability. And to that end, we've engaged an advisor and are discussing potential opportunities with several institutions. At this point, we're still in the process but we're realistic that this is just a challenge. There is no cookie-cutter model out there that says, here's how the best way to transfer red score to reduced lower cost of funds. But we're working on as diligent as we can, we remain cautiously optimistic that we had find some additional opportunities out there to improve the funding profile. But Tim, let's be clear we believe that HDFS provides a strategic advantage at Harley-Davidson. We also believe that the company benefited from having HDFS this year. It benefited both the company and our dealers and any arrangement must be with their company's long-term interest at heart and that includes underwriting, long-term commitment and certainly, recognition of any of the value that HDFS brings to the organization.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sharon, this is John. Number one is on a full-year basis, we're very pleased that SG&A was down $91 million driven by $83 million of restructuring. However, as you point out, SG&A was up in the fourth quarter, and that was driven largely by increased warr
componenttext: Sharon, this is John. Number one is on a full-year basis, we're very pleased that SG&A was down $91 million driven by $83 million of restructuring. However, as you point out, SG&A was up in the fourth quarter, and that was driven largely by increased warranty and recall costs. And we had several things happening in the quarter with that. As you might remember, we had a recall of our FL motorcycles. In addition to that, we did what we call a product program. It's not a safety recall. It's not a warranty -- because I made them [ph] outside of warranty, but it's something that we believe is important to the customer. And from a quality standpoint and related to tires for our touring motorcycles and so there was a charge in there for that. And then finally, our overall warranty rates were increased as we've seen some of our actuals come in a little higher than we expected.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, Sharon. What we said on last quarter when we announced that we were exiting the Buell product line is we expected $125 million of exit costs. That hasn't changed. Those costs were broken up into -- we'd hit in two lines of our P&L, one in the restru
componenttext: Sure, Sharon. What we said on last quarter when we announced that we were exiting the Buell product line is we expected $125 million of exit costs. That hasn't changed. Those costs were broken up into -- we'd hit in two lines of our P&L, one in the restructuring costs and the other in gross margin. As I mentioned before, the gross margin piece is to discount some of those bikes to clear the market. During the quarter, $71 million hit in restructuring. So for the motorcycle segment, we had $221 million on a full-year basis, $71 million of that was for restructuring at Buell. And that was about $10 million higher than we originally anticipated. However, the gross margin piece that hit in the fourth quarter was $45 million, and that was favorable in the same neighborhood as the unfavorability. So overall the $125 million is on track. However, restructuring piece is higher.

This $256 million looks like a meaningful uptick, even adjusted for that $15 million warranty charge. headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, a couple of points, Rod, is, one, as timing -- in SG&A, timing always comes into play, and so the fourth quarter is a little bit higher. The other thing is, is there maybe a little bit confusion. Because through the first three quarters, we had SG&A
componenttext: Well, a couple of points, Rod, is, one, as timing -- in SG&A, timing always comes into play, and so the fourth quarter is a little bit higher. The other thing is, is there maybe a little bit confusion. Because through the first three quarters, we had SG&A expenses for MV Agusta and then they now have been pulled back. But other than what we've provided as far as the productivity or the restructuring savings going forward, I can't provide a whole lot more than that.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: But the MV Agusta would be, if you're pulling that out now, I would imagine that, that would lower the pace of that operating expense. And it looks like historically, it's picked up maybe $5 million or $10 million in the fourth quarter. It is a little bit
componenttext: But the MV Agusta would be, if you're pulling that out now, I would imagine that, that would lower the pace of that operating expense. And it looks like historically, it's picked up maybe $5 million or $10 million in the fourth quarter. It is a little bit larger. Is there anything else that you can point out as unusual?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, nothing beyond regular timing things that happen in any given quarter. I would suggest to look at the full year number going forward and again, some of the restructuring savings that we expect to get next year out of SG&A.
componenttext: No, nothing beyond regular timing things that happen in any given quarter. I would suggest to look at the full year number going forward and again, some of the restructuring savings that we expect to get next year out of SG&A.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And this year, you produced 223,000 bikes and you sold 243,000. And you talked about a 5% to 10% decline in production. But there was also this year, you produced 8% or 9% fewer motorcycles than you sold. So are you suggesting that you're anticipating lik
componenttext: And this year, you produced 223,000 bikes and you sold 243,000. And you talked about a 5% to 10% decline in production. But there was also this year, you produced 8% or 9% fewer motorcycles than you sold. So are you suggesting that you're anticipating like a double-digit decline in sales next year? Could you just maybe elaborate a little bit on that?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't provide any forward-looking information on retail sales. What I can say, Rod, is that we ended the year where we wanted to be in the retail inventories in the United States. We feel that we're at the right inventory level for the size of the busi
componenttext: We don't provide any forward-looking information on retail sales. What I can say, Rod, is that we ended the year where we wanted to be in the retail inventories in the United States. We feel that we're at the right inventory level for the size of the business that we have, and we'll continue to adjust going forward. And we'll manage inventories very aggressively, and we'll manage our supply in-line with demand. Your point is valid. I can't help you out more, as the bases are very different between our shipment base versus our home retail sales base. But that will have some play in percentages.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Right, but it just looks like accounting for that inventory correction. You have a pretty either conservative, or sort of pessimistic view on the outlook for sales this year.
componenttext: Right, but it just looks like accounting for that inventory correction. You have a pretty either conservative, or sort of pessimistic view on the outlook for sales this year.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we believe that the 5% to 10% is an appropriate look, given what we see in the economy and the price competition that we would expect in 2010.
componenttext: Well, we believe that the 5% to 10% is an appropriate look, given what we see in the economy and the price competition that we would expect in 2010.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the HDFS business, could you tell us what your allowance for losses was as a percentage of receivables in the quarter? And is it the same on a managed basis, including the off-balance-sheet receivables?
componenttext: On the HDFS business, could you tell us what your allowance for losses was as a percentage of receivables in the quarter? And is it the same on a managed basis, including the off-balance-sheet receivables?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The allowance at the end of the quarter is $150 million or about 3% of the on-balance sheet receivables, pretty consistent with where it was at the end of the third quarter. The provision in the quarter was about $31 million. And we had about $30 million
componenttext: The allowance at the end of the quarter is $150 million or about 3% of the on-balance sheet receivables, pretty consistent with where it was at the end of the third quarter. The provision in the quarter was about $31 million. And we had about $30 million in charge-offs, so you can see not a lot of change in that allowance balance. Now remember in the off-balance-sheet, we don't provide a reserve per se. What we do have is the retained securitization interest. And obviously, we have underlying assumptions for credit losses related to that, but that's entirely different. Now what John talked about was FAS 166 and 167. In the first quarter, those off-balance-sheet receivables will be coming back on the balance sheet. And we will be providing a reserve against them.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And could you tell us what the book value was of HDFS? And also what happens to the MV debt at this point?
componenttext: And could you tell us what the book value was of HDFS? And also what happens to the MV debt at this point?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The book value was in the neighborhood of $870 million. And again, when you get the financial, the 10-K, that will be broken out and be extremely clear. I'm sorry, Rod. What was the second question?
componenttext: The book value was in the neighborhood of $870 million. And again, when you get the financial, the 10-K, that will be broken out and be extremely clear. I'm sorry, Rod. What was the second question?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The MV Agusta debt, does that get classified as discontinued ops? Or is that retained?
componenttext: The MV Agusta debt, does that get classified as discontinued ops? Or is that retained?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, everything that's related to -- let me get back to you on that, Rod.
componenttext: No, everything that's related to -- let me get back to you on that, Rod.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just lastly, do you have the cash from operations from the industrial business, from the Motorcycle business specifically? You said you're going to be publishing that in your K.
componenttext: And just lastly, do you have the cash from operations from the industrial business, from the Motorcycle business specifically? You said you're going to be publishing that in your K.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now Rod, I said we're going to separate it all out, and I don't want it all now. If the cash from the operating business was in the range of $540 million of the $600 million in the range and that will be broken out in the 10-K.
componenttext: Now Rod, I said we're going to separate it all out, and I don't want it all now. If the cash from the operating business was in the range of $540 million of the $600 million in the range and that will be broken out in the 10-K.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I assume all the $117 million of CapEx was in that business?
componenttext: And I assume all the $117 million of CapEx was in that business?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. And again, I would like to say that certainly one of the indicators of a tough year, a positive indicator is the ability of the motor company to generate that much cash when we had net income of $70 million, as a tribute to an incredibly powerful bus
componenttext: Yes. And again, I would like to say that certainly one of the indicators of a tough year, a positive indicator is the ability of the motor company to generate that much cash when we had net income of $70 million, as a tribute to an incredibly powerful business model.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And that's net of your pension contribution and restructuring, right?
componenttext: And that's net of your pension contribution and restructuring, right?

componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

componenttextpreview: What was the restructuring cash this year?
componenttext: What was the restructuring cash this year?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't have that number. The overall restructuring expense is $221 million for the Motorcycle segment, and additional $3 million at HDFS. But out of the cash, we did have $230 million in pension contributions, $215 million in the fourth quarter.
componenttext: I don't have that number. The overall restructuring expense is $221 million for the Motorcycle segment, and additional $3 million at HDFS. But out of the cash, we did have $230 million in pension contributions, $215 million in the fourth quarter.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison from Robert W. Baird.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Craig Kennison from Robert W. Baird.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could go at the shipment guidance question again. In the past, you've disclosed whether you plan to ship more or less or reduce inventory in the channel? What's your view on that going into 2010?
componenttext: If I could go at the shipment guidance question again. In the past, you've disclosed whether you plan to ship more or less or reduce inventory in the channel? What's your view on that going into 2010?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know if we've typically provided that guidance. But right now, again, all that I can say, Craig, is that we ended the year right where we wanted to be. We'll continue to adjust aggressively the supply in line with demand. We do expect shipments to
componenttext: I don't know if we've typically provided that guidance. But right now, again, all that I can say, Craig, is that we ended the year right where we wanted to be. We'll continue to adjust aggressively the supply in line with demand. We do expect shipments to be down, but we're not going to give guidance on where we expect to end the inventories in the dealer network. You can be very assured that we will be managing it or working it very closely.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: What was the dealer point count at the end of 2009? And what do you expect it to be at the end of 2010?
componenttext: What was the dealer point count at the end of 2009? And what do you expect it to be at the end of 2010?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The dealer count is on Slide 12. It's 757 dealer points, which are mainline dealers as well as secondary retail locations. We do not provide guidance as to that number on a full-year basis for 2010. But what we have said is that in the next quarter, the f
componenttext: The dealer count is on Slide 12. It's 757 dealer points, which are mainline dealers as well as secondary retail locations. We do not provide guidance as to that number on a full-year basis for 2010. But what we have said is that in the next quarter, the first quarter of this year, we expect to lose approximately 15 or to have approximately 15 dealerships close in the first quarter.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Shifting gears to Buell, dealers that carry Buell will have excess working capital dollars. How would you expect those dealers to allocate those dollars? Do you have a product in mind that they might carry to fill that gap?
componenttext: Shifting gears to Buell, dealers that carry Buell will have excess working capital dollars. How would you expect those dealers to allocate those dollars? Do you have a product in mind that they might carry to fill that gap?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We got a Harley-Davidson brand, that's the best in the world. But if they're going to sell through their units, now the typical dealership did not have a tremendous floor plan of Buell's, but we'd certainly expect and hope that they would invest that mone
componenttext: We got a Harley-Davidson brand, that's the best in the world. But if they're going to sell through their units, now the typical dealership did not have a tremendous floor plan of Buell's, but we'd certainly expect and hope that they would invest that money in the Harley-Davidson brand.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're going to add, I think over time up to 150 international dealers. To what extent is there a channel-fill opportunity to get those dealers up to speed with inventory?
componenttext: You're going to add, I think over time up to 150 international dealers. To what extent is there a channel-fill opportunity to get those dealers up to speed with inventory?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't break out what that would be. And quite frankly, I don't know what that number would be. If you look in Europe, we feel pretty good about the dealer network. We got some dealerships to fill in here and there in Western Europe. But when you look i
componenttext: We don't break out what that would be. And quite frankly, I don't know what that number would be. If you look in Europe, we feel pretty good about the dealer network. We got some dealerships to fill in here and there in Western Europe. But when you look into moving into new countries, India will obviously have some dealer fill that goes in there. And then this year, we expect to open up five dealerships in India. So as we look at some of the countries that will have distribution expansion, and there will be some fill, but that's not a large percentage of the shipments by any means. Again, internationally, we typically -- what we call pipeline, the inventory is sent to a warehouse and the dealers draw from it. Because typically, the dealer shops are smaller and they keep 20-ish bikes on the floor, and then when they sell them, they draw up from a warehouse. So there is not a lot to put in the dealerships.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robin Farley from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robin Farley from UBS.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just your guidance in the last few quarters, gross margin has seemed very low, and then you've beaten that guidance and not surprising -- but trying to understand how to view your 2010 margin guidance so I wonder if you can tell us a little bit about what
componenttext: Just your guidance in the last few quarters, gross margin has seemed very low, and then you've beaten that guidance and not surprising -- but trying to understand how to view your 2010 margin guidance so I wonder if you can tell us a little bit about what surprised you in your fourth quarter gross margins that they came in so much higher than your guidance, which again seemed very low? So what wasn't factored in your guidance that helped gross margin in the fourth quarter to be above that? And then also, I wonder if you could give us some sense of what your Sportster mix might look like in 2010 just given the production shutdown in 2009? I'm trying to think about how that mix will look on a year-over-year basis and then just another question after that.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well in general, Robin, we're very pleased with the overall margin strength that we've had as a company. And as we look at margins, we were down on a couple of percentage points year-over-year and taking out the Buell, the one-time items that hit Buell in
componenttext: Well in general, Robin, we're very pleased with the overall margin strength that we've had as a company. And as we look at margins, we were down on a couple of percentage points year-over-year and taking out the Buell, the one-time items that hit Buell in the fourth quarter, overall margins for the year were only down 1.2 percentage points. And again, we feel extremely pleased that our ability to hold up gross margins, despite a 26% decline in shipments. Specifically to answer your question is that yes, we've been under -- our guidance has been below where we come in actuals. And I think it's largely driven by the incredible productivity that the operation's organization has generated. I couldn't be happier with the organization and unbuckling down and pulling forward productivity projects, and we'll be focusing on continuous improvement everyday. And that's really what's been the -- delivering more than what we expected. In the fourth quarter specifically, a little bit of it was the Buell piece. So we expected a larger cost in gross margin in the fourth quarter. And again, as I had mentioned, we got a higher cost in restructuring but a lower cost in gross margins...

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Although that would've only been maybe 100 of the 300 basis points higher. And then on the Sportster mix, can you address where you expect that to come in?
componenttext: Although that would've only been maybe 100 of the 300 basis points higher. And then on the Sportster mix, can you address where you expect that to come in?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't specifically give mix out by family. We, again, feel good about our overall inventories but we're probably a little bit heavier on Sportster inventories at this point. But all in all, we feel real good about where the inventories ended the year.
componenttext: We don't specifically give mix out by family. We, again, feel good about our overall inventories but we're probably a little bit heavier on Sportster inventories at this point. But all in all, we feel real good about where the inventories ended the year.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess without putting a specific number on it, can you just sort of make a general comment about the Sportster family? And how you think about that in terms of like your long-term strategy? I'm just trying to get a sense of whether we'd see something di
componenttext: I guess without putting a specific number on it, can you just sort of make a general comment about the Sportster family? And how you think about that in terms of like your long-term strategy? I'm just trying to get a sense of whether we'd see something different. Obviously, 2009 was a very -- so the timing of the production and the shutdown and all that would be probably a one-time kind of thing. Still trying to get a sense of whether we'd see similar mix as we've seen in the last 10 years. Just with a general comment like that even if you don't put a number on it.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Keith. We continue to see the Sportster being an important part of the lineup. Obviously, we just announced today that we're launching a new model called the 48, which is another extension, if you will, of that line, sort of in the dark-custom fam
componenttext: This is Keith. We continue to see the Sportster being an important part of the lineup. Obviously, we just announced today that we're launching a new model called the 48, which is another extension, if you will, of that line, sort of in the dark-custom family that's intended to reach out to younger riders. We've had tremendous success with the dark-custom line up in terms of attracting young buyers to the Harley-Davidson brand. Unfortunately, because of the economy the way it is and maybe some of the younger folks having more difficulty having access to capital or borrowing, I'm sure it's impacted it somewhat. But overall, we feel pretty encouraged, and we continue to see that as just a very important part of our line up going forward.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of gross margin going forward, with the closure of Buell, can you quantify what impact on gross margin that would have if you didn't do anything else differently? Just sort of what the year-over-year benefit to margin would be just from closing B
componenttext: In terms of gross margin going forward, with the closure of Buell, can you quantify what impact on gross margin that would have if you didn't do anything else differently? Just sort of what the year-over-year benefit to margin would be just from closing Buell. And then also trying to think about -- you talked about your -- I don't know if you've given exact timing about when all of the cost saves would be in place in your -- I know your initial target, you talked about by 2014 for the specific December announcement in York and so just wondering if you would, sort of when you expect the full cost save in York to be in place by?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to Buell, next year, our margins, we expect to be between 32% and 33 1/2%. Buell will be a very small part of that. We still have some Buell to sell through. I don't know the impact year-over-year. Buell had a lower gross margin but it was a
componenttext: With regards to Buell, next year, our margins, we expect to be between 32% and 33 1/2%. Buell will be a very small part of that. We still have some Buell to sell through. I don't know the impact year-over-year. Buell had a lower gross margin but it was a very small part of the overall business. So I don't know the quantification of that but I don't think it would be all that great. With regards to York, we expect savings to start coming through this year. The bulk of the savings will be hitting in 2011, toward the back end of 2011 and certainly into 2012. We've got some York restructurings still happening in the very beginning of 2012, but the vast majority of all expenses will be in the 2012 actuals. And again, you can see the rollout in the restructuring slides that we have given in terms of when we expect the overall savings, and certainly York is a big driver of the overall piece.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes the line of James Hardiman from FTN Equity Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes the line of James Hardiman from FTN Equity Capital Markets.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a little bit more about the gross margin guidance for 2010, basically, you're looking for flat, maybe even a little bit down to up a little bit despite, you mentioned, I think $45 million of the Buell stuff not repeating in 2009. And then the restruc
componenttext: Just a little bit more about the gross margin guidance for 2010, basically, you're looking for flat, maybe even a little bit down to up a little bit despite, you mentioned, I think $45 million of the Buell stuff not repeating in 2009. And then the restructuring savings, which I think, based on my math, is 30-plus million dollars of restructuring savings that should hit the gross margin. What are the negatives that I should think about? Obviously, assuming down shipments, there's a little bit of deleverage there. But are there other negatives that get in the way of the gross margin, and it's not being a little bit better than what you're guiding to? How should I think about that?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, when we look at the margins -- you're thinking about it the right way, James, is that certainly productivity, which is made up of restructuring savings and continuous improvement savings along with -- will be partly offset by loss absorption. So with
componenttext: Yes, when we look at the margins -- you're thinking about it the right way, James, is that certainly productivity, which is made up of restructuring savings and continuous improvement savings along with -- will be partly offset by loss absorption. So with shipments being down 5% to 10%, that would certainly be a negative. And in any given year, we've got costs that inflate, inflation in the plants and so on and so forth. But the bigger piece would be loss absorption and lower volumes.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: It looks like you're no longer separating out corporate expenses as a separate line item. Does that now show up in SG&A? And then just in terms of interest expense, you kind of touched on this, the interest expense was higher in the quarter. Normally, the
componenttext: It looks like you're no longer separating out corporate expenses as a separate line item. Does that now show up in SG&A? And then just in terms of interest expense, you kind of touched on this, the interest expense was higher in the quarter. Normally, the majority of that is in HDFS. How should we think about that going forward?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The corporate expenses yes, James, they are now in SG&A, and when you get the 10-K, we'll break out the two business segments, and the corporate expenses will largely fall into the Motorcycle segment. Okay? But you're absolutely right, the way we're prese
componenttext: The corporate expenses yes, James, they are now in SG&A, and when you get the 10-K, we'll break out the two business segments, and the corporate expenses will largely fall into the Motorcycle segment. Okay? But you're absolutely right, the way we're presenting it now does not have corporate expenses, and we'll break those out for you -- we won't break out corporate expenses but those expenses will be in the Motorcycle segment when we break out it in the 10-K.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So that's at least part of the reason why the SG&A was a little bit inflated versus prior quarter, prior years? And then how about on the interest expenses side, should we expect the interest expense to continue at the ink level going forward at sort of c
componenttext: So that's at least part of the reason why the SG&A was a little bit inflated versus prior quarter, prior years? And then how about on the interest expenses side, should we expect the interest expense to continue at the ink level going forward at sort of current rates or how should we think about that?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let's spend a minute on that. It's mentioned in the preamble that HDFS repaid $600 million of the high-interest debt that we took out in February. As you recall in February, the company made the decision to borrow $600 million in order to continue to lend
componenttext: Let's spend a minute on that. It's mentioned in the preamble that HDFS repaid $600 million of the high-interest debt that we took out in February. As you recall in February, the company made the decision to borrow $600 million in order to continue to lend to our credit-worthy customers, as well as to our dealers for floor planning. The debt was issued at the ink level and the funds were pushed down to HDFS. Because we've always managed HDFS as a stand-alone entity, which means we expect HDFS to fund themselves and we expect the appropriate returns on their equity, it was done with the understanding that they would pay the funds back when the liquidity improved. It was basically a bridge in an illiquid market. So in the end, the repayment of the EGI [ph] debt does not impact the consolidated earnings at all, but it will more accurately reflect the economics of HDFS going forward. Consequently, in the corporate, beneath operating income or beneath EBIT, will be the income or the interest expense which will be much higher year-over-year in 2010 because it will include the interest from the hedged $600 million.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of India, you got the emissions restrictions pulled. Can you talk a little bit about the likelihood of getting the tariffs pulled? And how you think about this sort of the size of the market with and without the current tariff structure?
componenttext: In terms of India, you got the emissions restrictions pulled. Can you talk a little bit about the likelihood of getting the tariffs pulled? And how you think about this sort of the size of the market with and without the current tariff structure?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The only thing we can say about the tariffs -- I mean we're actively engaged with all of our contacts in Washington and working to try to do everything we can to get those either reduced or removed. I think we feel good about the Indian market in general.
componenttext: The only thing we can say about the tariffs -- I mean we're actively engaged with all of our contacts in Washington and working to try to do everything we can to get those either reduced or removed. I think we feel good about the Indian market in general. The excitement of the consumer there is at a high level. When you look at the recent auto show where we displayed, I mean the interest in our product, in our brand was just incredible. So we are in the process of setting up our first five dealerships. We hope to have those executed mid-year time frame, and we have high expectations for that market over the long-term.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And your last question comes from the line of Ed Aaron from RBC Capital Markets.
componenttext: And your last question comes from the line of Ed Aaron from RBC Capital Markets.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Keith, could you maybe kind of just talk about your forward outlook now versus 90 days ago? And the reason I asked the question is so last quarter, you tightened the 2009 production range toward the upper end of where you had it before, and then you kind
componenttext: Keith, could you maybe kind of just talk about your forward outlook now versus 90 days ago? And the reason I asked the question is so last quarter, you tightened the 2009 production range toward the upper end of where you had it before, and then you kind of came in toward the lower end of that and guided production down for 2010. I'm just wondering if your big-picture view of the world has changed much in the last three months and I had a couple of other questions after that.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Not a lot. I think, as we've sort of indicated through the whole call, I think we tend to be somewhat conservative in our outlook. And I think that's because we just have a lot of uncertainty around the consumer coming back into the market place here in t
componenttext: Not a lot. I think, as we've sort of indicated through the whole call, I think we tend to be somewhat conservative in our outlook. And I think that's because we just have a lot of uncertainty around the consumer coming back into the market place here in the very near term. I will tell you this, if you set aside the economy and the uncertainty in the economy, I couldn't feel better about where we're at. I mean we have accomplished a lot, I can't even tell you how proud I am of the whole team here, not just here in Milwaukee, but throughout the whole system. I think we've done a lot of the heavy lifting that needs to be done. I think we've made a lot of the tough decisions that we needed to be made. I think we're putting a foundation in place that I certainly feel good about, I think we all feel good about. And so, the outlook, in that respect, I feel better than I did 90 days ago. In terms of the economy and where the consumer is, I probably feel about the same.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
