componenttext: Good morning. My name is Sarah, and I will be the conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Harley-Davidson First Quarter 2010 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] I'd now like to turn the call over to the Director of Investor Relations, Ms. Amy Giuffre. You may begin your conference.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sarah, and welcome to Harley-Davidson's First Quarter 2010 Conference Call. This call is being webcast live on harley-davidson.com, where you also find slides containing supporting details. The slides can be accessed by clicking on Investor Rel
componenttext:
Thank you, Sarah, and welcome to Harley-Davidson's First Quarter 2010 Conference Call. This call is being webcast live on harley-davidson.com, where you also find slides containing supporting details. The slides can be accessed by clicking on Investor Relations, then Events and Announcements. 
Our comments today will include forward-looking statements that are subject to risks that could cause actual results to be materially different. Those risks include, among others, matters we have noted in our latest earnings release and filings with the SEC. Harley-Davidson disclaims any obligation to update information in this call.
This morning, you will hear from Harley-Davidson's CEO, Keith Wandell; CFO, John Olin; and President of Harley-Davidson Financial Services, Larry Hund. At the close of prepared comments, we will open the call for your questions. We ask that each caller ask only one question, and we appreciate your cooperation. So let's get started. Keith?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, thank you, Amy, and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call. As we noted in our earnings release, we are making good progress on a number of fronts with some encouraging directional improvements.We recorded earnings of $0.29
componenttext:
Well, thank you, Amy, and good morning, everyone, and thanks for joining us on the call. As we noted in our earnings release, we are making good progress on a number of fronts with some encouraging directional improvements.
We recorded earnings of $0.29 a share from continuing operations, which are the best earnings we have posted since last year's first quarter. Worldwide dealer retail sales of our motorcycles declined 18.2% in the quarter compared to the first quarter of 2009. And this was the smallest quarterly year-over-year decline since the last year's first quarter and the rate of decline lessened throughout the first quarter. 
We returned Harley-Davidson Financial Services to profitability, with operating income of $26.7 million.  Given all the difficulties of the past year, this is especially welcome news that reflects extremely well on the team at HDFS. 
We are on track with our restructuring activities, including the transformation underway at our York, Pennsylvania factory.
We believe dealer inventory is at an appropriate level in aggregate for our current market and our expectations for the year. Managing supply in line with demand will continue to be a priority for our company. And we are moving full speed ahead with our go-forward business strategy. So let me say thanks at the outset to all of our employees, dealers and suppliers for all the hard work and efforts [ph] to deliver the results that we are seeing. 
There's no doubt that we still have a long way to go, and it will continue to be a bumpy road on a number of fronts, given the uncertainty that remains in the economy and ongoing consumer caution. Still, it's good to see the progress that's occurring as a result of the actions that we've put into motion last year to strengthen Harley-Davidson and to grow the reach of the brand.
Our entire team is moving with great purpose and speed as we implement our go-forward business strategy with a focus on global growth and continuous improvement. So let me just take a couple of minutes to highlight a few of the things that are unfolding through our strategy in contributing to our momentum.
Like last year's Iron 883 motorcycle, the new 48 that we introduced this January is getting great traction. The 48 is the latest in our Dark Custom series of motorcycles designed to appeal to young adults. And in particular, we're having a hard time keeping it in our dealerships. We are seeing good results from two marketing programs that are currently underway. Our competitive bike exchange has generated a marked increase in trade-ins from competitive bike owners, with many of them moving over to one of our Touring bikes.
Once more, this program is succeeding on one of its main objectives, which is to let people know that our dealers are taking in competitive trade-ins. And the Ride Easy Guarantee is exceeding its target goals for selling the remaining non-current model year new motorcycles.
In March, Women's Garage Party month attracted more than 25,000 women to dealerships to learn about and get more comfortable on our bikes. Dealers enthusiastically embraced this program, holding some 450 garage parties. And many of the women attending are enrolling in our Rider's Edge New Rider Course. And anecdotally, dealers are reporting a positive sales impact.
We are reinvigorating our customer experience and events in a number of ways. At Daytona Bike Week last month, we moved our primary show venue from the convention center to a street event in the heart of the action across the street with dealership. We repositioned our Demo Ride Program at Daytona to reach him a more competitively-focused audience. And we conducted more than 8,300 demo rides during that bike week.  And for the first time, even non-riders could experience the feel of a Harley for themselves on stationary dynamometers. 
On the international front, we continue to expand our footprint. Last month, we announced the appointment of five dealerships in India. And I'm pleased to announce that at 7:45 a.m. this morning, India Standard Time, our new dealer in Mumbai took the first official booking of a Harley-Davidson motorcycle order in India, a 2010 XL 1200N Nightster. The international dealer network is expanding elsewhere as well. We're opening a dealership in Ecuador this month. And in May, the first of four newly-appointed dealers will open in Mexico.
Every year, we conduct Harley Owners Group officer training in various sites across the country. Two weeks ago, about 1,200 of these loyal enthusiasts were in Milwaukee for training. And more than a third of them were from international markets that represented over 25 countries. H.O.G. has more than 1 million members worldwide. And I can tell you from the time I spent with these members of this local chapter officers training, they are unbelievable ambassadors for our brand. So as you can see, there's an incredible amount of activity underway to support our growth strategy, and I've just barely scratched the surface.
Turning for a moment to continuous improvement, the restructuring of our York operations is well underway and the project is on target and on schedule and is exceeding our expectations. The physical restructuring and cultural change processes are on schedule, as is the outsourcing of non-core operations.
We have implemented the work rule changes in the new contract and our employees are involved and engaged. And in March, the plant had two days of weather-related closings, yet we still met the full-month production schedule, as a result of the improved productivity and efficiencies that exceeded our target. In short, we have seen a significant accomplishment from this facility, which is a testament to the commitment and focused effort by the entire team at York and our union leadership.
In Milwaukee, we're also on target with our restructuring activities. We expect to largely complete the consolidation of Powertrain Operations by the end of the second quarter. And moving forward, we will remain intently focused on identifying the competitive gaps and closing those gaps wherever they exist in our operations. We believe there are still many opportunities to improve efficiency, flexibility and cost competitiveness and align production across our operations.
So in summary, we're making good progress and we're seeing some encouraging signs, even as we continue to deal with the level of uncertainty in the global economy. The Harley-Davidson brand remains powerful and strong, with great appeal to both current and new customers in the U.S. and globally. We have a great conviction on our-go forward strategy is focusing our company in the right direction and that we are executing our strategy with the appropriate urgency.  Now let me turn it over to John Olin for a more detailed look at the financial results.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Keith, and good morning, everyone. During the first quarter, Harley-Davidson motorcycles and related products revenue from continuing operations was down 18.9%. This was expected as we shipped 28.1% fewer motorcycles than the first quarter of last
componenttext:
Thanks, Keith, and good morning, everyone. During the first quarter, Harley-Davidson motorcycles and related products revenue from continuing operations was down 18.9%. This was expected as we shipped 28.1% fewer motorcycles than the first quarter of last year. Income from continuing operations and earnings per share were both down, as a result of lower revenue and the impact of ongoing restructuring activities.
Moving on to retail sales on Slide 10. During the first quarter, our dealers' retail sales of Harley-Davidson motorcycles were down 18.2% on a worldwide basis as compared to last year. While an 18% reduction is disappointing, it was not unexpected given the overall economic conditions. Despite lower overall retail sales, we have made some encouraging progress on the retail front. On a sequential basis, comparing the last quarter of 2009 to the first quarter of 2010, we saw an improvement in the rate of retail sales decline in the U.S. and international markets. In addition, the Europe region posted sales increases for the second consecutive quarter. 
Regarding market share, our U.S. market share decreased by 2.3 percentage points in the first quarter, as we lapped a strong first quarter 2009 share increase of 8.2 percentage points and as we continue to face significant price competition from many of our competitors. 
Now let's talk about the health of the U.S. dealer network on Slide 11. First, and I know you've heard me say this numerous times, but it's important to reiterate that we remain committed to aggressively managing the supply of motorcycles in line with demand. We believe this will help protect our premium brand, which ultimately helps keep the dealer network strong. 
As we exited the first quarter, U.S. dealers' retail inventory was down over 23,000 units for the first quarter of 2009 and considerably from the peak in 2006. As Keith mentioned, we feel that the U.S. dealer inventory level is appropriate as we begin the 2010 selling season. However, our dealers are carrying a higher level of previous model year motorcycles than they normally do at this time of year, primarily due to the steep decline in retail sales experienced in the second quarter of 2009.
We are supporting our dealers' efforts to sell through these motorcycles. Keith talked about our efforts during the quarter, including the Ride Easy Guarantee, which offers value added incentives on the purchase of certain previous model year custom motorcycles and special financing for certain qualified purchasers of previous model year Sportsters. Also during the quarter, we offered a program which encouraged competitive owners to trade in their bike for a new Harley-Davidson. This program successfully drove targeted consumers into the dealerships and encouraged sales during the early spring.
The U.S. dealer network remains profitable. Through the first three months of the year, we lost only six dealer points versus a forecast of up to 15 dealer point closures. The start of the selling season was a welcome improvement to all our dealers who persevered through a very long winter. We do expect more dealers to close due to financial issues. And as we've said before, we believe that some contraction of the dealer network is healthy at this time.
As we move forward, we have several levels of insight into our dealer financials through our Motorcycle business, as well as through HDFS. We have realistic expectations and are taking a proactive approach to maintain a healthy dealer network. Our international dealer network remains healthy as well. And we believe there is potential to add 100 to 150 international dealer points through 2014, as we have stated in our strategic plan.
On Slide 12, you will see wholesale shipments to our dealers for the first quarter were down 28% compared to last year. Shipments in the quarter were in line with our expectations and resulted in significantly lower dealer inventory than one year ago. Sportster represented 15.3% of shipments, down 7.2 percentage points from last year. Conversely, Touring mix increased 7.9 percentage points, aided by strong Tri Glide sales and continued strength of our high-end offerings. This adjustment in mix continues to balance deals inventory that has been disrupted by the economic crisis. 
As you may recall, we increased Sportster production in the first half of 2009 in anticipation of a more price-conscious consumer, preference skewed toward the higher-end models. So we significantly reduced productions of 2010 Sportsters in the fourth quarter of last year.  Still, retail inventories of 2009 model year Sportsters remained high as we entered into the first quarter. Also, keep in mind that last year, shipments of the new Iron 883 started in the beginning of the first quarter. And this year's new Sportster, 48 did not start shipping until later in the first quarter. For the second quarter, we expect to ship between 55,000 and 60,000 Harley-Davidson motorcycles to our worldwide dealers, which is in line with last year's second quarter shipments of 58,000 units.
On Slide 13, you'll see revenue in all categories of the motorcycle and related product segments were down in the first quarter. The 20.0% decrease in Harley-Davidson motorcycle revenue during the first quarter was primarily the result of lower shipments, partially offset by favorable shipment mix and foreign currency exchange rates. As retail sales, shipments and revenue have been down due to the recession. We have been intensely focused on improving our cost structure and structuring the business to be stronger and more profitable in the future. 
Throughout 2009, we announced significant restructuring efforts that will reduce administrative costs, eliminate excess capacity and increase focus on core operations. During the quarter, we incurred $48.2 million in restructuring expenses. We remained on track to deliver the expected full year total cost and savings associated with our restructuring activities, which are summarized on Slide 14. 
On Slide 15, you'll see gross margin in the quarter was 36.6%, a half percentage point below the same quarter last year. As expected, gross margin was positively impacted by significantly more favorable mix, as I explained earlier. Mix favorability was partially offset by unfavorable manufacturing costs, due mainly to loss absorption.
Productivity in our operations continues to be strong, especially considering the consolidation taking place in our Powertrain Operation and the transformation underway at our York facility. First quarter gross margin exceeded our full year guidance, largely due to strong mix shift between Touring and Sportster. As the year progresses, we anticipate Sportster mix will end up in line with the historical range, and we continue to expect full year gross margin will be between 32% and 33.5%.
On Slide 16, operating margin as a percent of revenue for the first quarter was 12.2%, which was impacted by $94.5 million of lower gross margin and higher restructuring costs of $13.3 million, partially offset by lower operating expenses. 
Now moving on to our Financial Services segment. On January 1, we adopted FAS 166 and 167. On Slide 17, you will see a summary of the adjustments to implement those accounting changes. As a result of the adjustments, HDFS recorded assets and liabilities associated with the securitization transactions previously recorded as off balance sheet. The largest impacts were due to recording of approximately $1.9 billion in finance receivables and related debt, as well as a $41.0 million one-time charge to retained earnings.
HDFS' quarterly results, one of our big headlines today, are on Slide 18. In the first quarter, HDFS posted a $26.7 million profit, an improvement of over $15 million compared to last year. We believe that with the adoption of FAS 166 and 167, our financials for HDFS will provide a more transparent, easier to understand view of the business. Having said that, over the next several quarters, the year-over-year reconciliation as is presented on this slide will be impacted by comparability issues due to the extensive accounting changes from last year.
The key drivers for the quarter improvement were: Net interest income was favorable $36.4 million compared to last year, as a result of the increase in on-balance sheet receivables and an improvement in the net interest spread, as the cost of funds of HDFS has decreased. The provision for retail credit losses, which is associated with on-balance sheet held for investment retail receivables, was $28.5 million higher compared to the first quarter last year, as all receivables are now on balance sheet. Importantly, our credit risk assumptions in the retail portfolio did not change significantly from the prior quarter.
The impact of the provision for wholesale receivables is favorable compared to last year on a 29% smaller wholesale receivable balance from the prior year. And operating expenses were lower during the first quarter, as a result of restructuring savings in the business. The $2 million all other line primarily reflects the net effect of the fact that we no longer have gain on sale accounting. And the items that existed last year were income on retained securitization interest, servicer fees, low comp adjustments and the impact of impairment charges associated with retained securitization interest.
After three quarters of losses, we are pleased to see HDFS return to profitability. Lower cost of funds, improving credit loss trends and improving values of repossessed motorcycles have all contributed to a strong quarter at HDFS, which Larry will tell you more about now.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, John. During the first quarter, HDFS originated $374 million in retail motorcycle loans, down 21% compared to last year, primarily due to lower retail sales of Harley-Davidson motorcycles in the U. S. HDFS' retail market share of new Harley-Davids
componenttext:
Thanks, John. During the first quarter, HDFS originated $374 million in retail motorcycle loans, down 21% compared to last year, primarily due to lower retail sales of Harley-Davidson motorcycles in the U. S. HDFS' retail market share of new Harley-Davidson motorcycle sold in the U.S. was down nearly five percentage points to 42.1% in the first quarter compared to last year, as dealers are reporting more cash buyers in the market.
Also, we are seeing increased activity from competitors, particularly in the prime-rated customer segment. At the end of the first quarter, of the approximately $6.6 billion of net finance receivables, $5.6 billion were retail and $1 billion were wholesale. We continue to see good credit performance on early-stage delinquencies and defaults for loans originated after we made significant underwriting adjustments in January 2009. In the first quarter, 80% to 85% of our new loan originations were prime compared to our historical experience of approximately 75% prior to these underwriting changes. 
Now moving on to delinquencies and losses on Slide 20, where you'll see the 30-day delinquency rate for managed retail motorcycle loans at the end of the quarter was 4.57%, which is better than both the comparable quarter-end results in 2008 and 2009.
Our increased collection staffing levels, modified collection strategies and changes in underwriting have enabled us to effectively manage delinquency levels and bring them down compared to last year, despite high unemployment in the U. S. 
Annualized retail credit losses improved by 58 basis points to 2.83% for the first quarter of 2009, driven by lower frequency of loss and improvement in the recovery values of repossessed motorcycles.
So in conclusion, HDFS remains the primary source of funding for Harley-Davidson wholesale and retail motorcycle lending, and our profit this quarter is encouraging. We continue to make progress as our cost of funds has decreased and the performance of our portfolio has improved compared to last year. With unemployment near 10% and ongoing economic challenges, we'll continue to watch losses and delinquencies closely. We believe our underwriting criteria are appropriate, and we will continue to evaluate them on an ongoing basis.  Now I'll turn it back to John.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Larry. As most of you know, we are currently engaged in reviewing our strategic options to find more diversified and cost-effective funding in order to meet HDFS' goal of providing credit while delivering appropriate returns and profitability. The
componenttext:
Thanks, Larry. As most of you know, we are currently engaged in reviewing our strategic options to find more diversified and cost-effective funding in order to meet HDFS' goal of providing credit while delivering appropriate returns and profitability. The process is progressing and we are considering several potential scenarios. HDFS' return to profitability reinforces that we do have options and we will make the right decisions for the long term.
On Slide 21, you'll see our overall cash position at the end of the quarter. On March 28, we had $1.48 billion of cash and marketable securities. This is a significant welcome improvement and liquidity from just one year ago. And we believe it is in an appropriate level, given the uncertain economy. At end of the quarter, HDFS had approximately $900 million of available liquidity through bank credit and asset-backed conduit facilities. HDFS is currently in the process of negotiating the bank credit facility and asset-backed conduit facility. We expect negotiations will be complete by the end of April.
Our cash strategy continues to require a minimum of 12 months of projected liquidity in cash and/or other credit facilities. 
Now I'll review the remaining Harley-Davidson financials on Slide 22. I'd like to highlight a couple of items on this slide. First, with regards to operating cash, despite the large reduction in motorcycle shipments and the restructuring spending that we incurred, we were able to generate operating cash of over $200 million during the first quarter, with the motor company generating $61.6 million in operating cash. 
Regarding our tax rate, if you recall, last year, we incurred a tax charge due to a change in the Wisconsin tax law, which did not reoccur this year but drove the first quarter tax rate up to 45.4% last year. This year, our first quarter effective income tax rate from continuing operations was 47.2%. The increase was generally due to a $13.3 million tax charge associated with the taxability of Medicare Part D reimbursements under the recently-passed healthcare bill and the expiration of the research and development tax credit. As a result, we now expect our 2010 full year effective income tax rate from continuing operations to be approximately 40.5%.
On Slide 23, you'll find the summary of the MV Agusta business, which is presented as discontinued operations. During the first quarter, we posted an operating loss of $6.8 million and we wrote down the carrying value of MV Agusta's assets, resulting in a non-cash charge of $28.6 million net of related tax benefits. As we noted in the release this morning, we are currently in discussions with potential buyers for MV Agusta.
Looking forward to the remaining quarters of 2010, we continue to expect that the global economies will remain challenging. As we have said, we'll take a conservative approach to shipment volumes, as we continue to aggressively balance supply in line with demand. On a full year basis, our shipment, gross margin and capital expenditure guidance for 2010 remains unchanged, and they are noted on Slide 24.
As we look back on the first quarter of 2010, we were pleased to see some improvement in the retail sales rate from previous quarters, and profitability returned to HDFS. We look forward to coming quarters, as our sales season progresses and we prepare to launch our 2011 model year motorcycles in July. We'll continue to take the necessary actions to manage through the economic challenges and execute our long-term strategy. And now let's open the call up to your questions.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Tim Conder.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from Tim Conder.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: John, or Keith, either one, can you give us any additional color on used bike price trends, what you're seeing out there? And then one of the things you cited back in January on your conference call as related to used bike prices was you're concern about
componenttext: John, or Keith, either one, can you give us any additional color on used bike price trends, what you're seeing out there? And then one of the things you cited back in January on your conference call as related to used bike prices was you're concern about the Japanese and their clearing of non-current inventory. Just collectively maybe give us an update on that. And then also more of a housekeeping item, the FX impact on both gross margin and operating expenses in the quarter.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Starting out with used bike prices, as we look at repos as a proxy for used bike prices and I think we mentioned last quarter that we've seen some firming up in the last quarter of 2009. And since November, we've seen repos improve all the way to the firs
componenttext: Starting out with used bike prices, as we look at repos as a proxy for used bike prices and I think we mentioned last quarter that we've seen some firming up in the last quarter of 2009. And since November, we've seen repos improve all the way to the first quarter and now slightly above year-ago levels. I think, Tim, your next question was on price competition, and we're seeing a similar level of price competition in the first quarter as we saw in the fourth quarter of last year. And we're seeing deals on motorcycles anywhere from $500 a bike to $5000, so nothing has really changed quarter-over-quarter in that front. As far as the FX on gross margins, that was unfavorable by $4 million and FX on operating expenses was unfavorable by $3 million during the quarter.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So I mean, it sounds though like your concern entering the year here related to the Japanese to continue to clear inventory. It sounds like that's substantially reduced, given what you're seeing in used bike prices. Is that fair or are you still worried t
componenttext: So I mean, it sounds though like your concern entering the year here related to the Japanese to continue to clear inventory. It sounds like that's substantially reduced, given what you're seeing in used bike prices. Is that fair or are you still worried that maybe that could come back and bite you somehow?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, what we're seeing is exactly what we thought we would see as far as price competition. And that's clearly what we're seeing.
componenttext: No, what we're seeing is exactly what we thought we would see as far as price competition. And that's clearly what we're seeing.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Craig Kennison [Robert W. Baird].
componenttext: Your next question comes from Craig Kennison [Robert W. Baird].

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: You've come a long way to get the scarcity value of the brand back, but is there any concern among dealers about a lack of available supply and might you have to ease on that strategy a bit?
componenttext: You've come a long way to get the scarcity value of the brand back, but is there any concern among dealers about a lack of available supply and might you have to ease on that strategy a bit?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Craig, this is Keith. I mean, that's one of the things that we're constantly talking about, and there's varying views on this. I think it varies from dealer to dealer as well because some dealers have sold more product than others. So we are looking at th
componenttext: Craig, this is Keith. I mean, that's one of the things that we're constantly talking about, and there's varying views on this. I think it varies from dealer to dealer as well because some dealers have sold more product than others. So we are looking at these things sort of across the system. And as we mentioned in the call, we think that the efforts that we've made to bring inventories in line, we think we're at an appropriate level given how we see the rest of the year unfolding. And we didn't change our guidance on the rest of the year shipments, and we do have, I would say, dates in place. We're looking at specific dates where we'll continually make decisions about production, both plus or minus, as we go forward. But right now, we think in aggregate, we're pretty much where we thought we needed to be, and we're going to continue to manage at those kind of levels.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Ed Aaron [RBC Capital Markets].
componenttext: Your next question comes from Ed Aaron [RBC Capital Markets].

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: On HDFS, when you considered the degradation of the market share and their improvement in loss rates, I mean, is there almost any consideration to maybe easing credit a little bit after the tightening that you did over the last couple of years?
componenttext: On HDFS, when you considered the degradation of the market share and their improvement in loss rates, I mean, is there almost any consideration to maybe easing credit a little bit after the tightening that you did over the last couple of years?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We looked at it our underwriting criteria every month. And we make modest adjustments or tweaks. But we think we're in a good spot right now. And we think we're balancing the availability of credit out there in the dealer network, with very prudent underw
componenttext: We looked at it our underwriting criteria every month. And we make modest adjustments or tweaks. But we think we're in a good spot right now. And we think we're balancing the availability of credit out there in the dealer network, with very prudent underwriting standards. And I think those are reflected in our results. So I think right now, we've got a good balance. But we will continue to look at it every month, as we go forward.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: They came back on at about 2.6%, which is a little lower than our on balance sheet receivables before. And the reason for that is -- these came from securitizations that are all reasonably mature from 2006, 2007 and 2008. And therefore they've, sort of, p
componenttext: They came back on at about 2.6%, which is a little lower than our on balance sheet receivables before. And the reason for that is -- these came from securitizations that are all reasonably mature from 2006, 2007 and 2008. And therefore they've, sort of, passed their peak loss curve at this point.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Rod Patch (sic)[Rod Lache][Deutsche Bank].
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Rod Patch (sic)[Rod Lache][Deutsche Bank].

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's Rod Lache. Just trying to reconcile your full year gross margin guidance, which is down quite a bit from Q1. Is that basically the mix that you're anticipating? Secondly, just as a follow up to that question on the price competitiveness, it doesn't r
componenttext: It's Rod Lache. Just trying to reconcile your full year gross margin guidance, which is down quite a bit from Q1. Is that basically the mix that you're anticipating? Secondly, just as a follow up to that question on the price competitiveness, it doesn't really appear that your U.S. market share is down all that much, if at all, from the full year 2009. Is this a market share level that you think you can sustain? And then lastly, 70% to 80% of your savings, it looks like should be in the SG&A. But your operating expense is down by about $3 million. Can you just, kind of, reconcile that and give us some sense of how we should be expecting SG&A to look this year?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first question was on first quarter margins, which were 36.6%, down about a 0.5 from a year ago. And yes, it's above our guidance of 32% to 33.5%, but certainly, we expected that, given the mixed shift between Touring and Sportsters. So during the qua
componenttext: The first question was on first quarter margins, which were 36.6%, down about a 0.5 from a year ago. And yes, it's above our guidance of 32% to 33.5%, but certainly, we expected that, given the mixed shift between Touring and Sportsters. So during the quarter, we shift in 7.9 percentage points, more of Touring. And that's because as we've seen all last year certainly into this year, the strong sales of those bikes certainly led by the Trike, as well as the new Ultra Limited and our Road Glide that we introduced last July. Conversely, our Sportster mix was down 7.2 percentage points. And again as we entered into the first quarter, we still had a fair amount of model year 2009 Sportsters. And so we moderated production, and therefore, shipments in the quarter due to that. And then as I mentioned on the call as well, as when we look at the year-over-year shipments between Iron 883 and the Forty-Eight, we shipped in much fewer Forty-Eights. And that was because a year ago, when the plant was still up and operating at the end of 2008, we were building forward for the introduction at our Winter Dealer Meeting. Because the plant was shut down this year in the fourth quarter, we didn't have that opportunity and again, got into production a little bit later in the first quarter. So that's a pretty significant mixed shift. And that drove $54 million of margin favorability, which pushed up the gross margin up about five percentage points. As we progress through the year, we expect our Sportster mix to normalize. And a lot of that mix favorability to reverse out. Rod, I think your second question was on price competitiveness. Can you repeat that?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, you're holding on to 55%, 56% market share in the U.S. market despite that. It's down year-over-year but that's against the Sportster promotion in Q1. Just, kind of, give us a sense of -- it's still an awfully strong market share versus what you had
componenttext: Well, you're holding on to 55%, 56% market share in the U.S. market despite that. It's down year-over-year but that's against the Sportster promotion in Q1. Just, kind of, give us a sense of -- it's still an awfully strong market share versus what you had for the full year last year. Are you thinking that this price competition, although it's out there just not having as much of an impact on your performance vis-à-vis the market?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Rod, this is Keith. Let me just jump in. What we're really focused on here is the brand. And we think and we believe that our brand is extremely strong. There's a tremendous passion amongst our core customers and outreach customers. Everything we're doing
componenttext: Rod, this is Keith. Let me just jump in. What we're really focused on here is the brand. And we think and we believe that our brand is extremely strong. There's a tremendous passion amongst our core customers and outreach customers. Everything we're doing is intended to promote our brand, strengthen our brand. And we think the people that are coming into our dealership to buy our product are focused strictly on buying a Harley-Davidson. And I think that's what you're seeing. And this is part of our strategy. It's part of our focus, business strategy going forward. And we're just not going to deviate from that.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the question on SG&A and the operating expenses?
componenttext: And the question on SG&A and the operating expenses?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, SG&A again, as we finished last year, we were $91 million favorable on a year-over-year basis on SG&A, it felt great about that. We don't provide forward guidance on SG&A. But we do have additional productivity savings or restructuring savings that w
componenttext: Yes, SG&A again, as we finished last year, we were $91 million favorable on a year-over-year basis on SG&A, it felt great about that. We don't provide forward guidance on SG&A. But we do have additional productivity savings or restructuring savings that we are on track to receive in the 2010 period. For the quarter, we were favorable by $3 million. We're $3 million lower SG&A spending this quarter. That was largely driven by favorable Buell and partially offset by increased investment in our International businesses. And in addition at HDFS, we're very pleased that the SG&A was down about 10% there as well, or about $3 million or $4 million.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Maybe just to clarify on your cable, it's like $50 million or $60 million of incremental savings in 2010 versus 2009. And you say 70% to 80% of that's going to be in SG&A. Is that a net reduction in SG&A that you're alluding to there? Or is that a gross n
componenttext: Maybe just to clarify on your cable, it's like $50 million or $60 million of incremental savings in 2010 versus 2009. And you say 70% to 80% of that's going to be in SG&A. Is that a net reduction in SG&A that you're alluding to there? Or is that a gross number that gets offset by something else?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well I think to start with, the 2009 base is a good place to start, but what we're talking and referring to though are restructuring savings that have come.  We could see other ups and downs as SG&A and the core base as we go through the year as well.
componenttext: Well I think to start with, the 2009 base is a good place to start, but what we're talking and referring to though are restructuring savings that have come.  We could see other ups and downs as SG&A and the core base as we go through the year as well.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from James Hardiman [FTN Midwest Securities Corp.].
componenttext: Your next question comes from James Hardiman [FTN Midwest Securities Corp.].

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Question on HDFS. As I recall correctly, the big debt covenant that you have to worry about is, sort of, a 10:1 debt-to-equity ratio. I guess first question, just calculating that, do you net out the cash? I mean, if you don't net out the cash, you're loo
componenttext: Question on HDFS. As I recall correctly, the big debt covenant that you have to worry about is, sort of, a 10:1 debt-to-equity ratio. I guess first question, just calculating that, do you net out the cash? I mean, if you don't net out the cash, you're looking at, sort of, 8x. If you do, it's more like 6x. How should I calculate that? And more generally, how should I think about that, going forward? Do you feel comfortable that, that's not an issue with the new receivables on the balance sheet? Or conversely, are you in negotiations to maybe get those covenants renegotiated?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: James, this is John. One, we do not net out the cash. But we feel very good as to where we're at with regards to the covenants. So as you pointed out, we did bring a lot of debt back on to the balance sheet with FAS 166 and 167. We need all of our covenan
componenttext: James, this is John. One, we do not net out the cash. But we feel very good as to where we're at with regards to the covenants. So as you pointed out, we did bring a lot of debt back on to the balance sheet with FAS 166 and 167. We need all of our covenants and certainly including the 10:1 debt to equity, but as well as some of the other covenants that are out there. And we're fine where we sit today.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: More generally, sort of, given the receivables that you brought on to your balance sheet and where they stand from an aging perspective, when you think about that mix of debt, how should we think about that, going forward? When you balance, a lot of these
componenttext: More generally, sort of, given the receivables that you brought on to your balance sheet and where they stand from an aging perspective, when you think about that mix of debt, how should we think about that, going forward? When you balance, a lot of these new receivables are going to be getting paid off. I'm imagining that they're a couple of years old on average. When you balance that with the new receivables, you're bringing on to your balance sheet -- is the debt overall for HDFS going to be growing as we move through the year, given the current mix of debt? Or is it going to be, basically, staying the same? Sort of, how should I think about the rate of change of that debt, as we move through the year?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the rate of change is going to be dependent on the rate of receivables' growth or decline. And we'll continue to match the debt the best we can with the receivables. Remember, a lot of our receivables or a lot of our debt is self-liquidating through
componenttext: Well, the rate of change is going to be dependent on the rate of receivables' growth or decline. And we'll continue to match the debt the best we can with the receivables. Remember, a lot of our receivables or a lot of our debt is self-liquidating through the securitization. So as a lot of that gets paid down, the debt goes down. And we'll continue to do our best to match the two. And I think to John's point, if you take the $1.9 billion of receivables and debt that were added back on the balance sheet with FAS 166 and 167, all of that is self-liquidating and match funded because of the structure of the securitizations.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: So just basically, based on, sort of, where you think sales are going to be this year, we shouldn't expect that to continue to grow, as we move through the year? Is that...
componenttext: So just basically, based on, sort of, where you think sales are going to be this year, we shouldn't expect that to continue to grow, as we move through the year? Is that...

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't think we're giving any forward guidance on this. I think what we're saying is that we'll finance ourselves as we think is appropriate throughout the year. But we certainly raised a fair amount of debt in 2009. And I think that's left us well posit
componenttext: I don't think we're giving any forward guidance on this. I think what we're saying is that we'll finance ourselves as we think is appropriate throughout the year. But we certainly raised a fair amount of debt in 2009. And I think that's left us well positioned in 2010.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: But at the very least, we don't have to worry about that debt-to-equity ratio, getting from 8:1 to 10:1? This is clearly not on your radar at this point?
componenttext: But at the very least, we don't have to worry about that debt-to-equity ratio, getting from 8:1 to 10:1? This is clearly not on your radar at this point?

componenttextpreview: We feel very comfortable where those relationships are. And again any funding that we do in 2010 will be for 2011. We're fully funded for 2010.
componenttext: We feel very comfortable where those relationships are. And again any funding that we do in 2010 will be for 2011. We're fully funded for 2010.

componenttextpreview: Keith, you talked about in your prepared remarks the ongoing opportunities, in terms of continued cost improvement. I'm just wondering, have you looked at Kansas City at all? Is there any, kind of, future opportunities there?
componenttext: Keith, you talked about in your prepared remarks the ongoing opportunities, in terms of continued cost improvement. I'm just wondering, have you looked at Kansas City at all? Is there any, kind of, future opportunities there?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, yes. I mean, we're looking at every one of our operations. And, sort of, using the transformational labor agreement that was negotiated at York as a benchmark, if you will, particularly in terms of work rules and flexibility and those kinds of thing
componenttext: Well, yes. I mean, we're looking at every one of our operations. And, sort of, using the transformational labor agreement that was negotiated at York as a benchmark, if you will, particularly in terms of work rules and flexibility and those kinds of things. And we are working with all of our union representatives as well in each of our facilities, identifying performance gaps and how do we get better. And so clearly, each one of our facilities is under review for the opportunities that we have for improvement, both in cost, in manufacturing flexibility and those kinds of things.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just on HDFS, in terms of the process, you guys have been evaluating scenarios for a while. Can you give us some, kind of, sense of how close you might be in terms of finding more diversified and cost-effective funding there?
componenttext: And then just on HDFS, in terms of the process, you guys have been evaluating scenarios for a while. Can you give us some, kind of, sense of how close you might be in terms of finding more diversified and cost-effective funding there?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: At this time, Felicia, we can tell you is we've engaged an advisor in discussing potential opportunities with several institutions. We're being realistic as far as the challenge ahead of us to do something. But we remain cautiously optimistic that we can
componenttext: At this time, Felicia, we can tell you is we've engaged an advisor in discussing potential opportunities with several institutions. We're being realistic as far as the challenge ahead of us to do something. But we remain cautiously optimistic that we can find additional opportunities or improve the funding profile for HDFS. I would say that with HDFS, returning to profitability, reinforces that we have options. And we're certainly ought to do those; best for the long term of the company.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Robin Farley [UBS].
componenttext: Your next question comes from Robin Farley [UBS].

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your full year production guidance, it seems to imply, because of the next three quarters, would basically be flat production. Should we interpret that as roughly your expectations for what retail sales will be in the next three quarters? In other words,
componenttext: Your full year production guidance, it seems to imply, because of the next three quarters, would basically be flat production. Should we interpret that as roughly your expectations for what retail sales will be in the next three quarters? In other words, as you're  trying to match supply and demand, is that a reflection of your expectations for flat sales?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Robin, this is John. Robin, you're right. We have our guidance out there, which is down 5% to 10%. And after the first quarter, we still feel that, that guidance is appropriate. We're down 18% in retail sales in the first quarter. And while disappointing,
componenttext: Robin, this is John. Robin, you're right. We have our guidance out there, which is down 5% to 10%. And after the first quarter, we still feel that, that guidance is appropriate. We're down 18% in retail sales in the first quarter. And while disappointing, it certainly showed improvement throughout the quarter. As far as a proxy for retail sales going forward, I'm not going to provide any forward look at retail sales. But just to say that the 5% to 10% production guidance that we have down versus year ago, as we feel comfortable with and we're sticking to that guidance.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: I know a lot of folks have asked the question already. And I understand the mixed impact was a 500-basis-point benefit. But I guess one of the reasons probably why that question keeps coming up is that last year, a lot of your margin guidance all year was
componenttext: I know a lot of folks have asked the question already. And I understand the mixed impact was a 500-basis-point benefit. But I guess one of the reasons probably why that question keeps coming up is that last year, a lot of your margin guidance all year was for 30% to 31% and you ended up over 32%, I guess I'm just trying to think about, whether your guidance is being conservative. I guess how would you compare it with your expectations for gross margins last year where you came in? And how you think about your guidance this year? In other words, do you feel like you need to have the same level of conservatism in your guidance that you did last year?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well again, similar to the production guidance, the guidance of 32% to 33.5% and we feel comfortable with that. Though we were pleased to beat that in the first quarter. But again, that is all explained by the mix. When we look at the rest of the gross ma
componenttext: Well again, similar to the production guidance, the guidance of 32% to 33.5% and we feel comfortable with that. Though we were pleased to beat that in the first quarter. But again, that is all explained by the mix. When we look at the rest of the gross margin block, the manufacturing was unfavorable by $24 million. But again within that, that was all driven by lost absorption and on the productivity that the plants are spinning out is very favorable. We hope and expect that to continue. But where we sit today, we feel pretty good about gross margins and are certainly on track to continue to hit our guidance of 32% to 33.5%. But again, that mix will most likely reverse itself, as we bring Sportster back to historical mix levels.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Is it fair to say last year, there were things that surprised you on the upside with margin guidance? But your gross margin this quarter wasn't really a surprise to you that this is fully within your expectations? The fact that the margin is this much hig
componenttext: Is it fair to say last year, there were things that surprised you on the upside with margin guidance? But your gross margin this quarter wasn't really a surprise to you that this is fully within your expectations? The fact that the margin is this much higher than the rest of the year, there's not an upside surprise to your expectations?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first quarter margin was in line with our expectations.
componenttext: The first quarter margin was in line with our expectations.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: My question relates to international, just any change in the competitive environment there? In addition, did you also see a, sort of, that improvement as we got into the selling season internationally, as we did in the United States?
componenttext: My question relates to international, just any change in the competitive environment there? In addition, did you also see a, sort of, that improvement as we got into the selling season internationally, as we did in the United States?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't really see much of the change competitively. We are extremely focused on our international growth strategy. We are on track to add a number of dealers that we've talked about in the past, between now and 2014. And we just keep learning that the p
componenttext: We don't really see much of the change competitively. We are extremely focused on our international growth strategy. We are on track to add a number of dealers that we've talked about in the past, between now and 2014. And we just keep learning that the passion for this brand in every country in the world is very high. And so we're continuing to put the organization in place to drive our international growth and the dealers in place to provide our products to our customers. And we feel good about what we're doing from an international growth perspective.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Did things pick up, as we entered the spring selling season, like you did in the North American region?
componenttext: Did things pick up, as we entered the spring selling season, like you did in the North American region?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we look at -- just taking the quarter, we were down 2.8% internationally. With again, as I had mentioned Europe being up, that's compared to last quarter of being down about 10%. We're thrilled with the very large improvement and decline in the sales d
componenttext: As we look at -- just taking the quarter, we were down 2.8% internationally. With again, as I had mentioned Europe being up, that's compared to last quarter of being down about 10%. We're thrilled with the very large improvement and decline in the sales decline internationally from a sequential basis quarter-to-quarter.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Patrick Archambault [Goldman Sachs].

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: It sounded like you said that the cadence of sales through the quarter improved quite a bit from January, February. And that was certainly borne out in a lot of people's channel checks. How much of that momentum would you have said was due to, kind of, a
componenttext: It sounded like you said that the cadence of sales through the quarter improved quite a bit from January, February. And that was certainly borne out in a lot of people's channel checks. How much of that momentum would you have said was due to, kind of, a little bit of, I guess, pent-up demand from bad weather? And how is that looking as we, sort of, head towards the back half of April here?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: Patrick, I'm not going to blame anything on weather. I will point out that early in February, there was snow on the ground in 49 states. But we're not going to lay anything off on weather. And whether there was an impact there or not, I don't know. What w
componenttext: Patrick, I'm not going to blame anything on weather. I will point out that early in February, there was snow on the ground in 49 states. But we're not going to lay anything off on weather. And whether there was an impact there or not, I don't know. What we are is pleased with the fact that throughout the quarter, we did see retail sales momentum increase throughout the quarter. I can't provide a look beyond that into April or into the second quarter.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: What's going on with interest expense, Edward, is that -- take you back to February of last year in the height of the liquidity crisis, Harley-Davidson, Inc. went out and borrowed $600 million of high-interest debt. At that time, it has a coupon of 15%. A
componenttext: What's going on with interest expense, Edward, is that -- take you back to February of last year in the height of the liquidity crisis, Harley-Davidson, Inc. went out and borrowed $600 million of high-interest debt. At that time, it has a coupon of 15%. And we pushed that down to HDFS. And it was on HDFS' books with the intention that when things got better and HDFS can fund themselves, that they would pay that debt back. So at the end of the fourth quarter HDFS paid back the -- I'm sorry. I think in  November of last year, HDFS paid back the $600 million to Inc. And that's what you're seeing is the year-over-year comparison is a full year quarter with a $600 million at the ink level versus only a very small portion of that a year ago. We borrowed the money in February and for a period of time, it resided at HDFS and a period of time,at corporate. So going forward, based on that $600 million, the interest expense that we have in the fourth quarter is more normal as to what you'd see going forward.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: The first quarter of this year is more normal, which we had at least $23 million-ish.
componenttext: The first quarter of this year is more normal, which we had at least $23 million-ish.

But at this point, we don't have any guidance out there on it. And as Keith had mentioned, we've got opportunities throughout the organization that we're looking at and we would expect to continue to drive continuous improvement as we go forward.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, I think we probably run the gross margin stuff into the ground but just real quick -- looking at the last couple of years, it looks like the first quarter gross margin was the best of the year, certainly in 2008 and 2009. Is there a seasonal patter
componenttext: First, I think we probably run the gross margin stuff into the ground but just real quick -- looking at the last couple of years, it looks like the first quarter gross margin was the best of the year, certainly in 2008 and 2009. Is there a seasonal pattern there? Are there some seasonal effects there that would suggest that, in general, first quarter margins are going to be better than the rest of the year? Second question is from international standpoint, I think the feeling out there is that the international markets generally probably lagged the U.S. in terms of the recovery and yet, your Interactional business appears to be doing a lot better. Is that basically a function of market share? And is that, sort of, a delta that we should continue to see through the year that the international markets are going to outpace domestic or how should we think about that?

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010

componenttext: On the gross margin, there's nothing, in particular, I would point to in the first quarter, in terms of gross margin.

headline: Harley-Davidson, Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 20, 2010
componenttextpreview: But on the international front, we have picked up market share in the last several years incrementally in the last five years, particularly in Europe. And I think as much as anything else, it's just a reflection of, again, the continued focus on putting t
componenttext: But on the international front, we have picked up market share in the last several years incrementally in the last five years, particularly in Europe. And I think as much as anything else, it's just a reflection of, again, the continued focus on putting the right kind of an organization in place and dealer network, et cetera to take advantage of the opportunities that exist in those international markets. You got to remember, I think, not too long ago when sales were a lot higher and we had some production constraints, we weren't even able to allocate as much production to the international markets. So we just continue to keep focused on that. We talked about the fact that we're going to add 100 to 150 dealers between now and 2014 to various regions of the world. We're on track with our strategy. And we just feel real good about what our folks are doing in that area.
